bibl.title: Letter from William Crawford Gorgas to Jefferson Randolph Kean, November 20, 1917

div1.p: Gorgas writes that he will comply with Kean's requests concerning the organization of the ambulance service in the United States.

div1.head: Letter from William Crawford Gorgas to Jefferson Randolph Kean, November 20, 1917
div1.opener:
wcg-hhw
Reed Dec 28
Ans Jan 9 1849
S. G. O. 201 Kean, Jefferson R.
WAR DEPARTMENT
OFFICE OF THE SURGEON GENERAL
WASHINGTON
November 20, 1917.
Colonel Jefferson R. Kean,
C/o Chief Surgeon,
American Expeditionary Forces,
France.
My dear Kean:
div1.p:
Yours of October 31st has just been received.
All the suggestions you make in your letter have been com-
plied with and I have written you on the subject. I in-
tend to run the ambulance section on this side just exactly
as you suggest.

I requested the Red Cross to take over two sections in
Salonica sometime ago in accordance with cablegram from
Pershing, which I understood as being your suggestion.

I am still uncertain as to what is the future of the
ambulance section. Your letter of the 31st does not say
anything about it. We have still five thousand men in camp
at Allentown. I am holding on to these men at the request
of the French Legation. But if you are not going to need
them they should be distributed through the various cantonments
to form the nucleus of ambulance sections, field hospitals, etc.,
for the troops that are going over. What will you have to do
over there if the ambulance section is abolished?

If the matter has not been settled by the time you get
this letter please write me fully. It is a subject none of us
understand here.
